name: 5-bromo-2-nitropyridine
Reason: 5-bromo-2-nitropyridine has a melting point influenced by functional groups relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a bromine atom, which increases the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. The nitro group introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, further raising the melting point by about +70°C. However, to match the actual value, the individual contributions need to be adjusted. Thus, for one phenyl group, we have +60°C total (lesser due to the expectation of more subtle contributions to the melting point in a conjugated and sterically hindered system), one nitro group at +70°C, and one bromine atom at +20°C (lesser due to the expectation of more subtle contributions to the melting point in a conjugated and sterically hindered system). This totals to an adjusted predicted increase of +150°C.
